Minute Entry for Initial Conference proceedings held on 8/5/2024 before Magistrate Judge James R. Cho. Appearances by Daniel Negless, Eliza J. McDuffie, and Katherine Ruth Rosenfeld for plaintiffs; Mark Galen Toews, Thomas Lindeman, and Cindy Arlana Singh for defendant. Case discussed. Plaintiffs brought this putative class action against New York City's Administration for Children's Services ("ACS") alleging constitutional violations in connection with the investigative practices of ACS. The Court entered the following pretrial schedule: parties to exchange automatic disclosures by 9/9/2024; no amendment of the pleadings or joinder of additional parties permitted after 4/30/2025 without good cause; and parties to complete fact discovery by 5/30/2025. The Court defers setting an expert discovery schedule at this time. By 11/5/2024, parties shall file a joint status report and advise the Court whether they would like a referral to the Court-annexed mediation program or a settlement conference at that time. (FTR 12:03-12:15.) (JDP)

ORDER granting 2 MOTION for Leave to File Document / Leave to Proceed under a Pseudonym by Jane Doe 1.Doe 1 brings this action along with eight other named plaintiffs and on behalf of those similarly situated against the New York City's Administration for Children's Services ("ACS"), alleging that "ACS has a widespread custom, policy, and practice of entering and searching families' homes by using coercive tactics... to make parents feel that they have no choice but to allow caseworkers to enter and search their homes." Compl. para. 7, Dkt. 1. Plaintiff Doe 1 has filed an unopposed motion, Dkt. 2, seeking leave to proceed under a pseudonym. The Court grants Doe 1's motion for the reasons set forth below.A district court, after balancing "the public interest in disclosure and any prejudice to the defendant," has the discretion to permit a plaintiff to proceed under a pseudonym if "the plaintiff's need for anonymity" outweighs the "countervailing interests in full disclosure." Sealed Plaintiff v. Sealed Defendant, 537 F.3d 185, 189-90 (2d Cir. 2008) (setting forth a multi-factor test for assessing a plaintiff's ability to proceed under a pseudonym). Here, a majority of the factors set forth in Sealed Plaintiff weigh in favor of granting Doe 1's motion to proceed under a pseudonym.First, this case "involves matters that are highly sensitive and [of a] personal nature," id. at 190 (alteration in original), including intimate partner violence and allegations of child maltreatment. See R.F.M. v. Nielsen, 365 F. Supp. 3d 350, 371 (S.D.N.Y. 2019) ("[F]acts supporting... findings of abuse, neglect, and abandonment are highly sensitive."); Doe v. Strategic P'Ships, Inc., No. 19-CV-695, 2019 WL 13253839, at *1-*3 (W.D. Tex. July 30, 2019) (allowing plaintiff to proceed under a pseudonym where the "complaint contain[ed] facts related to [plaintiff's] status as a survivor of intimate partner violence and details her ex-partner's pattern of stalking and harassment"). Second, "identification poses a risk of retaliatory... mental harm," Sealed Plaintiff, 537 F.3d at 190, because Doe 1 fears that revealing her identity would subject her to retaliatory harassment from her ex-partner. See Doe v. Smith, 105 F. Supp. 2d 40, 45 (E.D.N.Y. 1999) ("[C]ourts have allowed plaintiffs to proceed anonymously where disclosure of their identities created a risk of harm from third parties unaffiliated with the case."). Doe 1 alleges that she has already been repeatedly subjected to harassment by her former partner and that he was the one who made false reports about her to ACS. See Doe 1's Mem. of Law at 1, Dkt. 3. Doe 1 fears that revealing her identity would subject her and her son to further harassment. Id. at 56. Third, requiring Doe 1 to reveal her identity would result in her not pursuing her claim and could chill future litigation by survivors of intimate partner violence. See id. at 78.Fourth, Doe 1's minor child is "particularly vulnerable to the possible harms of disclosure," Sealed Plaintiff, 537 F.3d at 190, and protecting Doe 1's anonymity is necessary to protect the anonymity of her son. See, e.g., Smith v. Edwards, 175 F.3d 99, 99 n.1 (2d Cir. 1999) (using pseudonyms for the plaintiff and his family to protect the identity of his minor child); P.M. v. Evans-Brant Cent. Sch. Dist., No. 08-CV-168A, 2008 WL 4379490, at *3 (W.D.N.Y. Sept. 22, 2008) (finding that "the protection afforded to the minor would be eviscerated unless the parent was also permitted to proceed using initials"). Fifth, "the suit is challenging the actions of the government" rather than "that of private parties." Sealed Plaintiff, 537 F.3d at 190; EW v. N.Y. Blood Ctr., 213 F.R.D. 108, 111 (E.D.N.Y. 2003) ("[W]here a plaintiff attacks governmental activity, for example a governmental policy or statute, the plaintiff's interest in proceeding anonymously is considered particularly strong."). Sixth, there is no risk of prejudice to the defendant because Doe 1 is willing to disclose her identity to the defendant. See Doe 1's Mem. of Law at 9, Dkt. 3.Seventh, Doe 1's identity has thus far remained confidential. See Sealed Plaintiff, 537 F.3d at 190. Further, there is a weaker public interest in knowing Doe 1's identity because this is a putative class action. See Sealed Plaintiff, 537 F.3d at 190; EW, 213 F.R.D. at 111 ("[I]n a class action context challenging governmental action, the individual defendant's personal characteristics (such as credibility) are generally not in issue."). And finally, there is no alternative means of preserving Doe 1's anonymity. See Sealed Plaintiff, 537 F.3d at 190.In light of the numerous factors that support Doe 1's application, the Court grants Doe 1's motion to proceed under a pseudonym (Dkt. 2). Ordered by Judge James R. Cho on September 6, 2024. (THB) Modified on 9/8/2024 (JDP).

case_data.name: Gould v. The City of New York
case_data.plaintiff_description: A putative class of adult parents or legal guardians subject to investigations by the New York City Administration for Children's Services in which ACS caseworkers have used, are using, or will use coercive tactics to search their homes without a court order or exigent circumstances.
case_data.summary:
This is a case about alleged unconstitutional home searches by the New York City Administration for Children's Services (ACS). On February 20, 2024, the plaintiffs filed this putative class action lawsuit against New York City in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York. The plaintiffs alleged that that ACS conducts tens of thousands of warrantless, coercive home searches each year in which they threaten to call the police or take away people's children if they are not allowed into people's homes to investigate the residents. The plaintiffs sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging that ACS' tactics constitute a violation of the Fourth Amendment's protection against unlawful search and seizure. The plaintiffs sought to represent a class consisting of "all adult parents or legal guardians subject to ACS investigations in which ACS caseworkers have used, are using, or will use [similar] [c]oercive [t]actics to search their homes without a court order or exigent circumstances." Represented by the Urban Justice Center, the NYU School of Law Family Defense Clinic, Washington Square Legal Services, and private counsel, the plaintiffs requested declaratory relief, injunctive relief, damages, and attorneys' fees.

On April 18, 2024, the case was assigned to Judge Rachel P. Kovner and Magistrate Judge James R. Cho. As of January 2, 2025, the case is ongoing.

documents.title: Class Action Complaint and Jury Demand
documents.text:
Case 1:24-cv-01263-CLP   Document 1   Filed 02/20/24   Page 1 of 49 PageID #: 1
 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
EASTERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK 
EBONY GOULD, CURTAYASIA TAYLOR, 
SHAVONA WARMINGTON, SHALONDA 
Civil Action No. ___ 
CURTIS-HACKETT, CHRISTOPHER 
HACKETT, MARIANNA AZAR, MATHEW 
ENG, JANE DOE 1, and JANE DOE 2, 
individually and on behalf of a class of all others 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT 
similarly situated, 
AND JURY DEMAND 
Plaintiffs, 
 
-against- 
THE CITY OF NEW YORK, 
Defendant. 
 
โACS MADE IT CLEARโEITHER I LET THEM SEARCH MY HOME OR THEY 
WERE TAKING MY KIDS.โ 
The New York City Administration for Childrenโs Services Uses Highly Coercive Tactics to 
Illegally Search Tens of Thousands of Familiesโ Homes Every Year. 
 
Plaintiffs  Ebony  Gould,  Curtayasia  Taylor,  Shavona  Warmington,  Shalonda  Curtis-
Hackett,  Christopher  Hackett,  Marianna  Azar,  Mathew  Eng,  Jane  Doe  1,  and  Jane  Doe  2 
(โPlaintiffsโ)  on  behalf  of  themselves  and  others  similarly  situated,  by  and  through  their 
undersigned attorneys, as and for their complaint, allege as follows: 
PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
1.  One night, without warning, a mother in New York City hears a knock on the door. 
Her children are home with her. The family is cooking, or playing, or sleeping. 
2.  When the  mother opens the door, two government investigators are standing 
outside, loudly demanding to be let inside. She is surprised and confused. She asks what this is 
about. The investigators command the mother. You have to let us in. We need to look in your home. 
 

Case 1:24-cv-01263-CLP   Document 1   Filed 02/20/24   Page 2 of 49 PageID #: 2
 
We donโt need a warrant. Weโre going to get the police here if you refuse. Weโre not leaving until 
we come inside. If you donโt let us in, weโre going to take your children.  
3.  The mother has no choice, it seems. Terrified, she reluctantly opens the door and 
steps aside, and the investigators walk into her home. It is clear that there is no present danger to 
anyone in the home, but still the investigators search the home top to bottom. They look inside 
medicine cabinets, under beds, in closets and dresser drawers, in the refrigerator, and in cupboards. 
The mother does not know why this is happening. The children are scared by these strangers 
combing through their home. 
4.  The investigators demand to see the childrenโs bodies under their clothes. They tell 
the mother to leave them alone in a room with her children. The investigators command the 
children. Lift up your shirt. Pull down your pants. I need to see your chest, your legs, your back. 
The children are afraid, but they comply. Their mother cannot protect them from these strangers. 
The mother fears that if she does not acquiesce to the investigatorsโ demands, they will take her 
children at any moment. Her fear is reasonable; the investigators are telling her that might happen. 
5.  The investigators leave as abruptly as they arrived. They have threatened to return, 
even though they found no evidence that the children are in danger. There seem to be no rules and 
no laws to protect the mother and her children from this intrusion.  
*  *  * 
6.  The City of New Yorkโs Administration for Childrenโs Services (โACSโ) conducts 
this kind of invasive and traumatic entry and search inside familiesโ homes more than 50,000 times 
a year. That means every day well over 100 New York City families experience this harrowing 
violation.  
  2 

Case 1:24-cv-01263-CLP   Document 1   Filed 02/20/24   Page 3 of 49 PageID #: 3
 
7.  As part of its routine investigations into families, ACS has a widespread custom, 
policy, and practice of entering and searching familiesโ homes by using coercive tactics (the 
โCoercive Tacticsโ) to make parents feel that they have no choice but to allow caseworkers to enter 
and search their homes. For example, ACS caseworkers lie to parents about their rights, threaten to 
call the police, and even threaten to take the parentsโ children away if the caseworkers are not 
permitted to enter and search the home. ACS conducts the overwhelming majority of these entries 
and searches without a court order, without voluntary consent, and in the absence of any emergency. 
8.  During  these  searches,  ACS  routinely  rummages  through  entire  homes  and 
conducts untrammeled inspections of familiesโ most private spaces. ACS performs these sprawling 
searches irrespective of whether these intimate spaces have any connection to whatever allegations 
have been made about that particular family. 
9.  These coerced searches rarely result in determinations that the children require any 
protection. Less than 7% of investigations lead ACS to file petitions in Family Court alleging that 
parents committed wrongdoing of any kind. 
10.  Nor do these coerced searches enhance child safety. As ACS has acknowledged, 
data from the first years of the COVID-19 pandemic show that there is no increase in child 
maltreatment when ACS drastically reduces the number of home entries and searches. 
11.  The trauma inflicted by ACS predominantly and disproportionately falls on Black 
and Hispanic families. More than 80% of the parents and children subjected to ACS investigations 
are Black or Hispanic. One out of every two Black children in New York City has been subjected 
to an ACS investigation by the time they reach the age of 18. ACS has acknowledged the racial 
  3 

Case 1:24-cv-01263-CLP   Document 1   Filed 02/20/24   Page 4 of 49 PageID #: 4
 
impact of its investigationsโan ACS-commissioned report describes a โpredatory system that 
specifically targets Black and Brown parents.โ1  
12.  ACSโs widespread use of the Coercive Tactics to enter and search familiesโ homes 
violates the Fourth Amendment. There are three ways caseworkers may search a familyโs home to 
conduct investigations consistent with the Fourth Amendment: (1) obtain a court order, (2) act upon 
exigent circumstances that require an immediate search of the home, or (3) obtain voluntary 
consent. Warrantless home searches like those ACS conducts tens of thousands of times a year are 
โpresumptively unreasonable.โ Groh v. Ramirez, 540 U.S. 551, 559 (2004) (internal quotation 
marks omitted). 
13.  Under the New York Family Court Act, ACS has the ability โat all hoursโ to obtain 
court orders to enter and search familiesโ homes.2 These orders must be supported by โprobable 
causeโ and โspecify which action may be taken and by whom.โ3  
14.  ACS chooses to almost never seek these court orders. Across the nearly 53,000 
investigations ACS conducted last year, it sought only 222 court orders to search familiesโ homes. 
Even assuming ACS completed only one home search during each investigation (it typically 
conducts several), ACS sought court orders for just 0.4% of home entries. This means over 99.5% 
of  home  searches  that  ACS  conducts  are  โpresumptively  unreasonableโ  under  the  Fourth 
Amendment. 
 
1   Antwuan Wallace et al., New York City Administration for Childrenโs Services Racial Equity 
Participatory  Action  Research  &  System  Audit:  Findings  and  Opportunities,  National 
Innovation Service 14 (Dec. 2020) (draft report,) https://int.nyt.com/data/documenttools/draft-
report-of-nyc-administration-for-children-s-services-racial-equity-
survey/fc3e7ced070e17a4/full.pdf [hereinafter, Racial Equity Report]. 
2   N.Y. FAM. CT. ACT ยง 1034(2)(f). 
3   Id. ยงยง 1034(2)(b)(i), (2)(c). 
  4 

Case 1:24-cv-01263-CLP   Document 1   Filed 02/20/24   Page 5 of 49 PageID #: 5
 
15.  ACS rarely attempts to justify its warrantless home searches by relying on exigent 
circumstances. Of course, ACS can enter familiesโ homes without a court order or consent when it 
has grounds to believe a child is in imminent danger. But this case is not about the thankfully 
infrequent emergencies when warrantless searches are necessary to protect a childโs safety. This 
case is about the overwhelming majority of ACSโs more than 50,000 warrantless home searches 
every yearโaffecting more than 90,000 children and 70,000 caretakersโwhere no emergency 
grounds exist, even assuming the allegations under investigation are true. These allegations are 
typically non-urgent and frequently involve common occurrences, such as a child missing school 
without a doctorโs note, a child seen playing in a hallway, or a parent disagreeing with a schoolโs 
recommendation for special education services. 
16.  In the absence of exigent circumstances, rather than seeking court orders, ACS 
caseworkers frequently gain entry into and search familiesโ homes through coercion, untruths, and 
threats. For instance, ACS caseworkers misrepresent and withhold information from parents about 
their rights, threaten to involve the police (i.e., government agents with the ability to use force), and 
even directly threaten to take parentsโ children away in order to improperly enter and search 
familiesโ homes. Caseworkers routinely employ these Coercive Tactics multiple times during the 
same investigation.  
17.  ACSโs rampant use of the Coercive Tactics to conduct warrantless home searches 
is well known to Defendant City of New York. These practices have been meticulously documented 
by ACSโs own internal reports, the agencyโs staff, and the informational materials ACS provides to 
parents, as well as by academics, reports and testimony of advocates and investigated parents, and 
in several prior lawsuits.  
  5 

Case 1:24-cv-01263-CLP   Document 1   Filed 02/20/24   Page 6 of 49 PageID #: 6
 
18.  Nonetheless,  ACS  fails  to  provide  anything  close  to  adequate  training  to  its 
caseworkers about familiesโ Fourth Amendment rights during home searches. Instead of ensuring 
that its staff follows the law, ACS has created and continues to foster a regime of coerced 
acquiescence by using tactics that inculcate fear in parents that unless they cede to ACSโs demands, 
their children will be taken. Indeed, an ACS internal report describes how the agency creates 
pernicious incentives for caseworkers to โbe invasive and not tell parents their rights.โ4 
19.  Plaintiffs are nine parents who were subjected to ACSโs Coercive Tactics. These 
Coercive Tactics misled and intimidated Plaintiffs into believing they had no choice but to permit 
ACSโs warrantless home entries and searches in non-exigent circumstances. ACS deployed an array 
of Coercive Tactics over the course of the numerous home searches experienced by Plaintiffs: ACS 
threatened to take Plaintiffsโ children away if they did not let ACS into their homes; ACS threatened 
to call the police if Plaintiffs refused consent to entry; ACS told Plaintiffs the searches were 
โrequiredโ or that ACS โneededโ to search their homes; ACS abused and misrepresented its 
authority; ACS did not meaningfully inform Plaintiffs of their rights to refuse, limit, or revoke 
consent for ACSโs home searches; and ACS made public scenes at Plaintiffsโ front doors to 
intimidate Plaintiffs into letting them in.  
20.  Plaintiffsโ experiences are not isolated or unusual. They are consistent with and 
indicative of ACSโs widespread and customary practice of deploying highly Coercive Tactics to 
conduct warrantless searches of familiesโ homes in non-exigent circumstances in violation of the 
Fourth Amendment.  
21.  Plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and others similarly situated, bring this lawsuit 
to end these unconstitutional and unconscionable wrongs. 
 
4  Racial Equity Report, supra note 1, at 18.  
  6 

Case 1:24-cv-01263-CLP   Document 1   Filed 02/20/24   Page 7 of 49 PageID #: 7
 
JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
22.  This  Court  has  subject-matter  jurisdiction  over  Plaintiffsโ  claims  pursuant  to 
28 U.S.C.  ยงยง  1331  and  1343(a),  as  this  action  seeks  redress  for  the  violation  of  Plaintiffsโ 
constitutional and civil rights.  
23.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 2201 and 2202, this Court has jurisdiction to declare the 
rights of the parties and to grant all further relief deemed necessary and proper. Rule 65 of the 
Federal Rules of Civil Procedure authorizes injunctive relief. This Court has authority to award 
attorneyโs fees and costs under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1988.  
24.  Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1391(a) and (b) because 
Defendant City of New York resides in this District and a substantial part of the events or omissions 
giving rise to the claim occurred in the Eastern District of New York.  
JURY DEMAND 
25.  Plaintiffs demand trial by jury in this action.  
PARTIES 
Plaintiffs 
26.  Plaintiff Ebony Gould is a resident of Queens, New York. She is the mother of three 
children: N.G., an eighteen-year-old girl; X.D. a nine-year-old girl; and G.D., a seven-year-old girl 
(collectively, the โGould Familyโ). Ms. Gould is Black.  
27.  Plaintiff Curtayasia Taylor is a resident of Bronx, New York. She is the mother of 
two children: A.C., a twelve-year-old boy; and A.V., a seven-year-old boy (collectively, the โTaylor 
Familyโ). Ms. Taylor is Black. 
28.  Plaintiff Shavona Warmington is a resident of Queens, New York. She is the mother 
of six children: L.B., an eleven-year-old girl; P.W., an eight-year-old girl; E.W., a three-year-old 
girl; N.W.R. and A.W.R, one-year-old twins; and K.W.R., a newborn boy (collectively, the 
  7 

Case 1:24-cv-01263-CLP   Document 1   Filed 02/20/24   Page 8 of 49 PageID #: 8
 
โWarmington Familyโ). Ms. Warmington is Black.  
29.  Plaintiffs  Shalonda  Curtis-Hackett  and  Christopher  Hackett  are  residents  of 
Brooklyn, New York. They are the married parents of three children: C.X.H., a sixteen-year-old 
boy; S.Y.H., a twelve-year-old girl; and C.Z.H., a nine-year-old boy (collectively, the โHackett 
Familyโ). Ms. Curtis-Hackett and Mr. Hackett are both Black. 
30.  Plaintiffs Marianna Azar and Mathew Eng are residents of Brooklyn, New York. 
They are the married parents of one child: Y.A., a six-year-old girl (collectively, the โAzar-Eng 
Familyโ). Ms. Azar is white and Mr. Eng is Chinese-American.  
31.  Plaintiff Jane Doe 1 is a resident of Manhattan, New York. She is the mother of one 
child: A.D.1, an eight-year-old boy (collectively, the โDoe 1 Familyโ).5 Ms. Doe 1 is Black.  
32.  Plaintiff Jane Doe 2 is a resident of Queens, New York. She is the mother of three 
children: A.D.2, a fourteen-year-old-girl; B.D.2, a ten-year-old boy; and C.D.2, a four-year-old girl 
(collectively, the โDoe 2 Familyโ).6 Ms. Doe 2 and her children reside with her husband, the 
childrenโs father. Ms. Doe 2 is Hispanic. 
33.  Plaintiffs  shall  be  collectively  referred  to  herein  as  โPlaintiffsโ  or  โNamed 
Plaintiffs.โ 
Defendant 
34.  Defendant  City  of  New  York (the  โCityโ)  is  a  municipal  entity  created  and 
authorized under the laws of the State of New York. The City is authorized by the State of New 
York to maintain ACS, the City agency responsible for investigating and prosecuting allegations of 
child neglect and abuse. At all relevant times hereto, the City was responsible for the policies, 
 
5   This Complaint uses pseudonymous initials to protect the anonymity of the Doe 1 family. 
6   This Complaint uses pseudonymous initials to protect the anonymity of the Doe 2 family. 
  8 

Case 1:24-cv-01263-CLP   Document 1   Filed 02/20/24   Page 9 of 49 PageID #: 9
 
practices, supervision, and investigations into child abuse and neglect conducted by ACS, as well 
as the appointment, training, supervision, promotion, and discipline of all ACS personnel. 
35.  At all relevant times, the officials, supervisors, managers, caseworkers, agents, and 
employees of ACS were acting under the color of state law in the course and scope of their duties 
and functions as officials, supervisors, managers, caseworkers, agents, and employees of ACS and 
otherwise performed and engaged in conduct incidental to the performance of their lawful duties. 
The officials, supervisors, managers, caseworkers, agents, and employees acted for and on behalf 
of  ACS  with  the  power  and  authority  vested  in  them  as  officials,  supervisors,  managers, 
caseworkers, agents, and employees of ACS and Defendant City. 
36.  As the acts or omissions complained of in this Complaint are those of ACS,

II.  ACS MAINTAINS A WIDESPREAD POLICY, CUSTOM, AND PRACTICE OF 
COERCING CONSENT TO SEARCH HOMES WITHOUT A COURT ORDER OR 
EXIGENT CIRCUMSTANCES 
67.  Defendant City of New York knows that more than 50,000 times a year, ACS 
caseworkers will enter and search the homes of families subject to the agencyโs investigations. 
68.  Caseworkers use the Coercive Tactics to carry out these entries and searches in 
non-emergency circumstances instead of obtaining a court order or voluntary consent. 
69.  ACS  fails  to  provide  adequate  policies,  procedures,  training,  or  supervision 
regarding familiesโ Fourth Amendment rights with respect to home entries and searches. 
A.  ACS Maintains a Widespread Policy, Custom, and Practice of Using Highly 
Coercive Tactics to Enter and Search Familiesโ Homes 
70.  In order to legally conduct home searches in the absence of a court order or exigent 
circumstances, ACS must receive voluntary consent to enter and search the home.36 
71.  During tens of thousands of warrantless, non-exigent searches every year, ACS 
does not obtain voluntary consent to enter and search familiesโ homes. 
72.  To effectuate home entries and searches, ACS maintains a widespread custom, 
policy, and practice of coercing parents into allowing ACS caseworkers to enter and search their 
homes in violation of the Fourth Amendment. 
73.  ACS uses a series of Coercive Tactics to enter and search familiesโ homes without 
obtaining voluntary consent:

C.  ACS  Overwhelmingly  Fails  to  Seek  Court  Orders  to  Enter  and  Search 
Familiesโ Homes Despite the Availability of a Clear Process to Obtain Them 
98.  ACS has intentionally chosen to use the Coercive Tactics although a readily 
available legal procedure exists for obtaining a court order to enter and search familiesโ homes.  
99.  The New York Family Court Act establishes a clear process that is โavailable at all 
hoursโ of the day for caseworkers to obtain court orders (โEntry Ordersโ) to authorize home entries 
and searches in the absence of parental consent. Caseworkers can seek these orders in person, in 
writing, or by phone.56 
100.  The procedure for ACS to obtain Entry Orders under the Family Court Act is โthe 
same as for a search warrant under article six hundred ninety of the criminal procedure law.โ57

101.  As the Second Circuit explained in a New York City case, in ACS โinvestigations, 
a  Family  Court  order  is  equivalent  to  a  search  warrant  for  Fourth  Amendment  purposes.โ 
Southerland v. City of New York, 680 F.3d 127, 144 n.15 (2d Cir. 2012). 
102.  ACS may obtain an Entry Order only โwhere there is probable cause to believe that 
an abused or neglected child may be found on the premisesโ to which entry is sought.58  
103.  Family courts may only grant Entry Orders that are โnecessaryโ in light of the 
childrenโs safety and may only authorize actions that are โthe least intrusive to the family.โ  
104.  To issue an Entry Order, family courts must weigh factors including โthe nature or 
seriousness of the allegations,โ โthe potential harm to the child or childrenโ absent the search, the 
reliability of the report to the SCR, and the strength of the evidence supporting it.59  
105.  Despite clear standards and an available process to obtain Entry Orders at all hours 
of the day, ACS virtually never seeks Entry Orders to authorize the home entries and searches it 
conducts as part of nearly every investigation.  
106.  In 2023, ACS sought Entry Orders in just 0.4% of its investigations. It conducted 
52,873 investigations and made just 222 applications for Entry Orders.60

without a court order or claimed exigent circumstances.

207.  Plaintiffsโ cases exemplify how ACSโs widespread use of the Coercive Tactics to 
enter and search familiesโ homes causes significant and lasting trauma to the tens of thousands of 
families investigated by ACS each year.  
208.  Beyond  Plaintiffsโ  experiences,  numerous  studies  as  well  as  testimony  from 
psychological experts document the harm to parents and children that invasive ACS home entries 
and searches leave in their wake.  
209.  A paper in the peer-reviewed journal Archives for Pediatric Adolescent Medicine 
compared a group of families investigated for child abuse or neglect with a separate group of 
similarly situated families not subject to any investigation.87 It concluded that an โinvestigation 
predicted higher maternal depressive symptomsโ but did not bring about any positive effects on 
familiesโ social support, general functioning, education, or financial circumstances.88 
210.  Other psychological and sociological studies have similarly found that parents 
experience increased depression, โongoing anxiety,โ and โpowerlessnessโ during and after intrusive 
investigations into their family lives,89 suffering effects like โsleeplessness, weight loss, nausea, 
night-terrors, and depression.โ90 These detrimental effects are even more profound for children.91

CLASS ACTION ALLEGATIONS 
215.  Plaintiffs bring this action pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 under Rule 23(b)(2) of the 
Federal Rules of Civil Procedure on their own behalf and on behalf of a class of all persons similarly 
situated. 
216.  Plaintiffs seek to represent a certified Plaintiff class consisting of all adult parents 
or legal guardians subject to ACS investigations in which ACS caseworkers have used, are using, 
or will use the Coercive Tactics to search their homes without a court order or exigent circumstances 
(the โUnconstitutional Home Search Classโ or โClassโ). 
217.  This action is properly maintainable as a class action because all four requirements 
of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(a) are satisfied. 
218.  Numerosity. The members of the Unconstitutional Home Search Class are too 
numerous to be joined in one action, and their joinder is impracticable. ACS conducts more than 
50,000 investigations each year, nearly all of which include at least one home search. ACS obtains 
a court order or acts upon exigent circumstances in less than 2% of all its investigations. Although 
ACS has claimed that it obtains familiesโ consent for home searches during the remaining 98% of 
its investigations, the extensive public record and experiences of the Plaintiffs described in this 
Complaint establish that ACS maintains a widespread policy, custom, and practice of using the 
Coercive Tactics to unconstitutionally search familiesโ homes. Upon information and belief, the 
Unconstitutional Home Search Class consists of tens of thousands of people.  
219.  Commonality. There are numerous questions of law and fact common to the 
Unconstitutional Home Search Class. These include, without limitation: (1) whether ACS maintains 
a widespread policy, custom, and practice of using the Coercive Tactics to enter and search familiesโ

homes during ACS investigations; (2) whether ACSโs use of the Coercive Tactics violates the 
Fourth Amendment; (3) whether ACS knows about and is deliberately indifferent to the agencyโs 
widespread use of the Coercive Tactics; (4) whether ACS has failed to establish adequate policies 
or procedures to protect parentsโ Fourth Amendment rights during the tens of thousands of home 
searches ACS conducts each year; (5) whether ACS fails to adequately train and supervise 
caseworkers about parentsโ Fourth Amendment rights during home searches; (6) whether the Cityโs 
failure to maintain policies or provide adequate training or supervision regarding parentsโ Fourth 
Amendment rights causes ACSโs widespread use of the Coercive Tactics; and (7) whether ACSโs 
use of the Coercive Tactics causes harm to class members.  
220.  Typicality. The violations and injuries suffered by Plaintiffs are typical of those

used, are using, or will use the Coercive Tactics to enter and search their homes without a court
